Award.AwardTitle: Walking in Two Worlds: Engaging the Community and Future Native American Scientists in Environmental Science and Managing Natural Resources on Tribal Lands

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Native Americans exert sovereignty over vast amounts of United States land and water resources, yet are underrepresented in the disciplines that train our nation's future land and water resource managers. Native American resource managers must walk in two worlds, accommodating both traditional and modern methods that may come into conflict. Building on an existing, NSF-funded Manoomin Science Camp, the Walking Two Worlds (W2W) project will employ a systems view of resource management in considering a broad range of resource management issues affecting the region (including its lakes and wetlands, fisheries, forestry, wildlife, and air quality), with the goal of engaging the entire community in environmental and resource management issues of immediate relevance to the community. W2W will incorporate both Western science concerning the physical, chemical, and biological worlds, and traditional environmental knowledge, culture, language, and the judgment of elders. This holistic approach will not only facilitate effective resource management for the community, it will also serve as a 'hook' for engaging students and the community in STEM.

A partnership of the Fond du Lac Band (of Lake Superior Chippewa) and the University of Minnesota (UMN) planned collaboratively with the community, W2W will focus on community-inspired, participatory science research projects related to resource management and environmental science. W2W will be facilitated by local teachers, with former participants as mentors, researchers and resource manages as mentors, and UMN faculty as lecturers. W2W recognizes the critical importance of strong STEM education for natural resource management. Using a mixed-methods approach to external evaluation, the project will build knowledge on the contributions of the W2W holistic, systemic approach and theme of community resource management. This will provide the foundation for a future development project that builds a community of place-based learning and community-inspired research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This informal science-learning project sought to increase participation in STEM by Native American students. Native Americans have the lowest participation rate of any underrepresented groups in STEM fields. In many school districts, Native American students’ high school graduation rates are also the lowest. Walking in Two Worlds program worked with Ojibwe elders who have been conducting informal science camps to try to increase interest in STEM and increase high school graduation rates. When the elders started the camps more than 25 years ago, the original purpose was to increase the middle school completion rates. In the last 5 years, high school graduation by consistent camp attendees have been achieved; most are going to junior or 4 year colleges and at least one has started graduate school in engineering.

The students are learning traditional ecological knowledge as well as Western science. Students became very aware of climate change and how they may be affecting their reservation and animals and plants that are important in their culture, and that one way to practice science without completely adopting Western ways (and giving up their “Indianness” would be to work as resource managers for reservation government.  Also, some students have started to participate in science fairs and have done well (one student’s project was judged third best at the 31st Annual National American Indian Science and Engineering Fair (NAIVSEF)).

We hoped that a more holistic approach to providing STEM training, away from formal classrooms, and incorporated into relevant issues on reservations and everyday lives would help lower the barrier to learning STEM topics. After 4 years on this project and 5 years on previous NSF award, it is clear that the holistic approach works, and that a long-term commitment (as the two Ojibwe elders have shown) is necessary to achieve objectives. As non-Natives, the project leaders at the University of Minnesota had to earn the trust of the leaders of the Fond du Lac Reservation.  This show of trust came during the 3rd year of the prior project. This made working with the Resource Management personnel for the current project much easier and smoother.

We tried approaching other nearby reservations to gauge interest in supporting similar informal science camps but were not successful. There is no one method that can be transported from one reservation to the next because every tribal government works differently. The need for a long-term consistent funding remains a challenge.
